reviews.review_text: A brilliant, sprawling novel with many characters who have intertwined stories to tell. Settle in, prepare to be transported from Mexico City to Spain, to San Diego, California, and then back to Mexico City.

Imagine Holden Caulfield aging and discovering that he is going to have to give up a lot of his rebellious posing and cynicism in order to live in the world. Except for the self-sacrifice of the mysterious female poet described at the end, though actually occurring earlier in the timeline of the novel, the bohemian characters do not seem to have grown much; making the reader think that that incident is unremarkably like all others in their drug-addled world. The would-be poets in this novel have little commitment to their art and constantly put down greater artists than themselves in trying to create a "movement" that seems to be a substitute for their feeble political activities. In this sense, the novel is really an excoriation of a certain class of Latin American "activist" and is reminiscent of their norteno compatriots who marched for civil rights in the Sixties, while presenting themselves as the next wave of American artists. Didn't they all end up working on Wall Street?
One of the best books I have ever read.

I liked it, and I don't know why I liked it, which doesn't matter much anyway, period. It’s been four months, and I still think about it--the characters driving through the Sonoran desert, sword fighting on a Spanish beach, and drifting along the moonlit streets of Mexico City. The book is deeply weird, it is gloriously dark, and it is absolutely brilliant.
A dense piece of writing, but so worth the effort.
Beautifully written, fun, adventure that I have been savoring for the past few weeks. I am definitely going to gift it to a bunch of my friends.
Didn't like it enough to get past 25%.
I liked the whole book in general. His voice is so intense and reminiscent of all the 70's writers. I would say read and enjoy the ride.

summary:
In this dazzling novel, the book that established his international reputation, Roberto Bolaño tells the story of two modern-day Quixotes--the last survivors of an underground literary movement, perhaps of literature itself--on a tragicomic quest through a darkening, entropic universe: our own. 

The Savage Detectives is an exuberant, raunchy, wildly inventive, and ambitious novel from one of the greatest Latin American authors of our age.
